item.title: UK travel update: Amber list scrapped in overhaul of travel rules in England
item.description: Fully vaccinated travellers will also no longer need to take PCR tests, says the transport secretary.

item.title: Ruling limiting under-16s puberty blockers overturned
item.description: The appeal decision reverses a High Court ruling that under-16s would struggle to give informed consent.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban morality police replace women's ministry
item.description: The Taliban appear to have shut the women's affairs ministry and brought back a feared morality unit.

item.title: Papers can be served on Prince Andrew's US lawyer - judge
item.description: Virginia Giuffre is pursuing a civil case in New York against the prince over allegations of sexual assault.

item.title: Climate change: UN warning over nations' climate plans
item.description: Climate plans of more than 100 countries show we're heading in the wrong direction, the UN says.

item.title: Covid-19: Travel rules overhaul sees amber list scrapped
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Friday evening

item.title: David Gomoh murder: Gang members jailed for NHS worker stabbing
item.description: David Gomoh managed to stagger back home before dying in front of his family.

item.title: Covid vaccine and test passes to be introduced in Wales
item.description: People will need to show they have been vaccinated or had a negative test for clubs and large events.

item.title: Women threatened over maternity care bills
item.description: A debt collection company told some women that future visas for in the UK would be refused if they did not pay.

item.title: 'It's still sinking in!' - Raducanu on winning the US Open
item.description: British teenager Emma Raducanu tells BBC Breakfast about the "whirlwind" experience of winning the US Open.

item.title: Gas shortage 'threatens food security' says meat industry
item.description: A shortage of carbon dioxide could hit meat production and packaging, UK processors warn.

item.title: Three Chinese astronauts return to Earth after 90 days in space
item.description: The three men make a safe return after 90 days in space - China's longest ever crewed mission.

item.title: Chess icon sues Netflix for Queen's Gambit portrayal
item.description: Nona Gaprindashvili files a defamation lawsuit claiming she was incorrectly portrayed in the series.

item.title: Thailand Covid: Idle taxis used to grow food for out-of-work drivers
item.description: With Thailand's capital under tight Covid restrictions, taxis are being repurposed to grow food.

item.title: California fires: General Sherman and other sequoias given blankets
item.description: Fire-resistant blankets protect General Sherman and other sequoias as a California blaze closes in.

item.title: British Pie Awards: Meat pie triumphs despite rise of vegan bakes
item.description: The traditional bake rose to the top, beating a high number of vegan entries.

item.title: Pet cat missing for 10 years in Aberdeen reunited with owners
item.description: Forbes vanished in Aberdeen in 2011, and Neil and Lucy Henderson say finding him is a "dream come true".

item.title: The Wanted's Tom Parker opens up about his cancer diagnosis
item.description: Tom refuses to let cancer dominate his life after being diagnosed with an inoperable brain tumour.

item.title: Mosquitoes sucked up by traps that mimic breathing
item.description: More than 300 traps have been deployed in the French town of Hyères to catch mosquitos.

item.title: Sheringham 125-year-old shipwreck revealed by calm weather
item.description: The sunken vessel is rarely seen due to ever-changing conditions at sea.

item.title: 'There’s security but no money': Afghans settle into life under Taliban rule
item.description: In Mazar-i-Sharif, former army pilots are flying Taliban around and families are selling possessions for food.

item.title: US politician Nancy Pelosi heads to Chorley, Lancashire for G7 summit
item.description: The Lancashire town is hosting a meeting of presiding officers - including the US Speaker of the House.

item.title: Keira Bell case: What are puberty blockers?
item.description: Doctors can now judge whether under-16s can give informed consent to taking puberty blockers.

item.title: Aukus: Defence pact an awkward wake-up call for Europe
item.description: As Australia, the UK and the US seal a security pact, the EU does not quite know where to look.

item.title: The big problem of building waste and how to tackle it
item.description: How better technology and regulation could cut the waste generated by the construction industry.

item.title: Sir Clive Sinclair: Tireless inventor ahead of his time
item.description: The prolific innovator invented the pocket calculator and the ill-fated Sinclair C5 electric car.

item.title: Lil Nas X: Is the rapper the defining star of his generation?
item.description: The rapper has subverted hip-hop with his LGBT-positive lyrics, while dominating critics on social media.

item.title: Michael Gove: What will he do with beefed-up planning and levelling up job?
item.description: Michael Gove is known as a reformer and is now in charge of controversial planning changes.

item.title: Oasis Knebworth 1996: 'We had no fear'
item.description: Noel Gallagher on the new film marking 25 years since his old band's era-defining gigs.

item.title: Liberal Democrats: Is Ed Davey sticking to his promises?
item.description: We look at the performance of the party and its leader as the Lib Dem conference gets going.

item.title: Jamie Campbell: We need more stories from outside London
item.description: A new film tells the story of a boy who lives on a council estate and is obsessed with drag.

item.title: ECB to decide on Pakistan matches 'in next 48 hours' after NZ abandon tour because of 'security alert'
item.description: New Zealand men's team abandon their limited-overs tour of Pakistan following a New Zealand government "security alert".

item.title: 'A boycott of Afghanistan cricket wouldn't help the country's women's players'
item.description: Why a boycott of Afghanistan's men's cricket team would harm country's women's players.

item.title: What are the travel rules now and for half term?
item.description: The rules on foreign travel to and from England are being simplified.

item.title: Covid passports: How do I get one and when will I need it?
item.description: People in Scotland will need to be fully vaccinated to go to clubs, sporting events and concerts.

item.title: Long Covid: What is it and what are the symptoms?
item.description: Significant numbers have had long-term problems after recovering from the original infection.

item.title: Covid rules: What's in England's 'Winter Plan'?
item.description: Lockdown rules have changed across the UK, but some restrictions remain in place.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings?
item.description: Face coverings could become a legal requirement in England again if the NHS struggles this winter.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Flu jab 2021: Who’s eligible for a free vaccine?
item.description: This year's roll out has expanded in an attempt to shield against a double whammy of flu and Covid.

item.title: Is it safe to vaccinate our child? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about vaccinating 12-15 year-olds, the booster vaccine and other topics.

item.title: Hushpuppi - the Instagram influencer and international fraudster
item.description: How Nigerian Ramon Abbas went from a romance scammer to a so-called "Billionaire Gucci Master".

item.title: ‘Havana syndrome ’ and the mystery of the microwaves
item.description: The BBC investigates a mystery illness dubbed "Havana syndrome" that has affected American diplomats and spies.

item.title: 'The near-death experience that made me a top musician'
item.description: When Tony Kofi had a near-fatal accident, he had a vision of himself playing a musical instrument. It would change his life forever.

item.title: Chaos and confusion: The frenzied final hours of the Afghan government
item.description: Through interviews with insiders, BBC News has pieced together an account of how Afghanistan’s government unravelled.

item.title: 'I studied law in jail - now I want to change the system'
item.description: LaTonya Myers spent nine months in jail because she couldn’t afford bail - now she's helping others facing the same challenge.
